content.description:
A traverse from right to left on the bottom of Placque Rock.

Gets increasingly more balancy as you traverse left and up (usually) across the rock.
content.protection: Plaque Traverse never gets too far off the ground.   A spotter (or crash pad) is a good idea since there's a smaller rock parallel to the traverse that would hit your head if you land more horizontal than vertical.

content.description: 10 feet up, crimps and pockets. Many variations, V4-5 and up depending on where you go on the face. Use only natural features on the face. "Eliminate" the carved plaque holds and the arete.
content.protection: Two bolts on the top can be used to set up a top rope. Longer sling required.
content.location: Just to the right of the Plaque, go up. The most obvious route in the center of the face eliminating the plaque.

content.description:
Climb the left side of the face on Plaque Rock. This route starts directly under the plaque, heads right through the plaque (hence modification) and then up and out through the center of the face using small crimpers and pinches to get you to the top.

This is not a very long route, but it does get harder towards the top.
content.protection: There are two solid bolts behind the top of this rock.  Bring a couple medium length slings (5') to avoid rope drag.

content.description: The arete on the right side of plaque rock.  Difficult to judge which holds you should be going for until you're already there.  Lots of fun but too short!
content.protection: Use the top rope anchors atop plaque rock which should be approached from the left.

content.description: The furthest left climb on Plaque Rock.  Use the arete to get to the top - as simple as that.
content.protection: There are sturdy top rope anchors atop the rock, approach them from the left.  A short sling will reduce rope drag pretty efficiently.

content.description: Just like Plaque Traverse, this climb starts on the far right side of Plaque Rock and traverses left.  The difference is that all the holds above the base of the plaque (including the bottom left corner of the plaque) are OFF.  This results in very tricky feet on the left side.  Finish by turning the arete.
content.protection: A spotter is pretty important to make sure you don't fall into the low boulder behind the left part of the traverse.
